Table 1 Catalyst O 1 s peak area ( %) (OII+III)/(OI+II+III) Basic sites amount ( %) OI OII OIII Weak Medium Strong LaFeO3 41.1 54.2 4.7 0.59 18.4 30.9 50.7 LaCoO3 53.6 42.6 3.8 0.46 14.7 78.5 6.8 LaNiO3 30.4 63.5 6.1 0.70 7.9 71.6 20.5 La2O3 59.2 40.8 — 0.41 1.3 2.2 96.5 Lanthanum-based perovskite catalysts for the glycerol carbonylation to glycerol carbonate: Effects of oxygen defects and basicity Jia Ding Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization Jinghui Qin Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Shengyu Zhou Methodology Investigation Yuanhao Wu Methodology Investigation Chao Fan Methodology Investigation Yulong Li Methodology Investigation Jianguo Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green-Chemical Synthesis Technology, Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310032, China State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green-Chemical Synthesis Technology Institute of Industrial Catalysis College of Chemical Engineering Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310032 China State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green-Chemical Synthesis Technology, Institute of Industrial Catalysis, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310032, China ⁎ Corresponding author. LaBO3 (B = Fe, Co, Ni) perovskite catalysts were prepared by the sol-gel method. The physical properties and active sites were characterized by XRD, BET, SEM, TEM, XPS, EPR, and CO2-TPD. The results indicated that catalysts had fine perovskite structure and high crystallinity. The as-synthesized catalysts were used for the glycerol carbonylation with CO2 to glycerol carbonate (GC). The LaCoO3 exhibited high conversion and selectivity of 26.3 and 72.4 % at a reaction temperature of 150 °C for 12 h under CO2 pressure of 3 MPa in the presence of 2-cyanopyridine with DMF as the solvent. It was found that surface oxygen defects favored the glycerol conversion, while the high concentration of total weak and medium basic sites promoted the GC selectivity. The LaCoO3 also displayed excellent reusability performance, indicating its great potential in industrial applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Perovskite catalyst Lanthanum Glycerol carbonylation CO2 Glycerol carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, the biodiesel industry is growing rapidly, which is considered to be a green and sustainable process as compared to the petroleum industry [1]. However, how to consume a large quantity of byproduct glycerol has become a big challenge, which hinders the development of the biodiesel industry [2]. The catalytic conversion of glycerol to valuable chemicals is an attractive pathway to solve this problem [3]. Glycerol carbonate (GC) is one of the important products derived from glycerol, which has been widely used as a green solvent and raw material in the fine chemicals industry, as it has excellent characteristics including high boiling point, low non-toxicity, and biodegradability [4]. So far, several methods have been investigated for converting glycerol into GC, including transesterification of glycerol with carbonates [5,6], carbonylation of glycerol with urea [7–9], direct carbonylation with CO2 [10,11], and oxidative carbonylation with CO2 [12,13]. In comparison with other methods, direct carbonylation of glycerol with CO2 has received great attention due to the high atomic utilization and consumption of greenhouse gas CO2 [14,15]. The carbonylation of glycerol into GC is limited by the thermodynamic equilibrium [16–18]. To break such limitations, dehydrating agents were attempted to remove the by-product water [19–21]. The commonly used dehydrating agents include acetonitrile and 2-cyanopyridine [22]. Zhang et al. employed acetonitrile as a dehydrating agent to study the effect of surface properties on the catalytic activity of Cu/La2O3 catalyst [23]. Liu et al. also studied glycerol carbonylation using 2-cyanopyridine as a dehydrating agent on a CeO2 catalyst [24]. Although the improved conversion was achieved by adding dehydrating agents, the carbonylation of glycerol with CO2 still faces great challenges like low catalyst efficiency. In the last decades, research work has explored new catalyst systems to achieve high conversion. For example, the ZIF-67 catalyst with high specific surface area and good thermal stability facilitated the production of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and CO2 [25]. Liu et al. reported the transformation of CO2 and glycerol to glycerol carbonate over CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution with different Zr doping [26]. Li et al. explored mixed metal oxides derived from hydrotalcite-like compounds. Halogen ions (F −, Cl−, and Br−) and metal ions (Li+, Mg2+, and Zr2+) modified Zn–Al–La mixed oxides displayed good catalytic activity [27]. Li et al. found the basic sites of La2O2CO3–ZnO catalysts were active for this reaction, and medium basic sites exhibited higher activity than both low and strong basic sites [28]. Nagendra et al. reported that transition metals-doped (Zn, Cu, and Ni) CeO2 nanorods could improve the activation of CO2 by enhancing oxygen vacancies [29]. As advanced materials, perovskites (ABO3 type crystals) have been explored in many research fields, which, however, have never been attempted as catalysts for the carbonylation of glycerol into GC [30]. The A or B cations of perovskites can be substituted with elements possessing different sizes and valences, in order to introduce structural defects, which is a commonly used strategy to improve their catalytic activity [31–33]. Some of the perovskites have strong acidic and alkaline [34,35]. Because of their unique characteristics, perovskites have been widely used in solar energy conversion, electrochemistry, sensors, and catalysis with dramatic performance [36–38]. Turren-Cruz et al. explored perovskite-based materials to enhance charge carrier mobility, extend service lifetime, and improve efficiency as solar cells [39]. Undavalli et al. developed lanthanum nickel-reduced graphene for high-performance pseudocapacitors [40]. Mao et al. fabricated lanthanum nickel perovskite supported Pt catalyst for the methanol-reforming in the aqueous phase [41]. Phadtare et al. found that crystalline LaCoO3 perovskite could be used as a novel catalyst for glycerol transesterification, suggesting that perovskite is capable of activating and converting glycerol into highly valuable products [42]. Given the tunable properties and excellent catalytic performance, perovskite has great potential in the direct carbonylation of glycerol with CO2. In this work, a series of La-transition metal-based perovskite catalysts with different transition metals (Co, Fe, Ni) were prepared by the sol-gel method. Various characterization techniques were conducted to reveal the physicochemical properties of catalysts. The as-synthesized catalysts were employed in the carbonylation of glycerol into GC with 2-cyanopyridine as the dehydrating reagent. The effects of temperature, pressure, reaction time, and the amount of 2-cyanopyridine were studied. Moreover, a cycling test of LaCoO3 (B=Fe, Co, Ni) was examined to demonstrate the catalyst reusability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9 %, Macklin), iron nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3,·9H2O, 99.9 %, Macklin), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.9 %, Aladdin), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.5 %), and citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7·6H2O, 99.5 %, Aladdin) were used for the catalyst synthesis. Glycerol (99.5 %, Aladdin) and N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF, 99.5 %, Sinopharm), 2-cyanopyridine (98 %, Macklin), and diethylene glycol monomethyl ether (DEGME, 99 %, Macklin) were employed for the catalytic test. 2.2 Catalysts preparation LaBO3 (B = Fe, Co, Ni) perovskite catalyst was synthesized by the sol-gel method. Firstly, lanthanum nitrate (6 mmol) and transition metal nitrate (Fe, Co, or Ni; 6 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min. Then, a stoichiometric amount of citric acid monohydrate was added to the above solution. The final mixture was heated at 75 °C under vigorous stirring until the formation of a gel. The sample was dried at 110 °C for 12 h, followed by calcined at 300 °C for 1 h, and then at 700 °C for 5 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the LaBO3 perovskite catalyst was obtained. For comparison, the La2O3 catalyst was synthesized by the same method without adding transition metal nitrate. 2.3 Catalysts characterizations The structure of the LaBO3 perovskite catalyst was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD; PANalytical Empyrean powder diffractometer). The working voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA respectively. The patterns were collected with a 2θ range from 10 to 80° at a step of 5°/min. The N2 adsorption-desorption tests were carried out at 77 K on a Micromeritics Analyzer (ASAP 2460, Micromeritic Instruments, USA). The specific surface area (ABET) of the catalysts was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, while the pore size distribution was calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The morphology of the catalysts was observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM; HITACHI Regulus 8100) with an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. The related elemental distribution was analyzed by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford Ultim Max 65). The images of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were recorded on an FEI Tecnai G2 20 microscope operating at 200 kV. The element valence and distribution of the LaBO3 catalysts were investigated by employing X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Escalab 250Xi spectrometer) with Al Kα radiation. The surface oxygen defects were detected by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) at room temperature on a Bruker EMX PLUS EPR spectrometer. The basicity of the catalysts was evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD, AutoChem1 II 2920). Firstly, the catalyst was pretreated in N2 from room temperature to 100 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Then, the catalyst was cooled down to 50 °C in a He flow with a rate of 30 mL/min. The catalyst was exposed to high purity of flowing CO2 gas for 30 min, and then purged with flowing He gas at the same temperature for 30 min to remove the reversibly and physically bound CO2. Subsequently, the desorption process was conducted from 100 to 700 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min in the He stream. The signal of desorbed CO2 was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation A stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) equipped with a thermocouple and magnetic stirrer was used to investigate the catalytic performance of LaBO3 catalysts for the carbonylation of glycerol with CO2. Typically, 0.92 g of glycerol, 3.12 g of 2-cyanopyridine, and 10 mL of DMF were added to the reactor. Then, 0.2 g of catalyst was mixed with the above solution under stirring. After sealing tightly, the reactor was then pressurized with CO2 to 1–5 MPa at room temperature. Then, the reactor was heated up to 130–190 °C and kept for 6–18 h under continuous stirring. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled naturally to room temperature and depressurized. The liquid sample was separated from the mixture by centrifugation. The product was analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HP-50+ (30 m × 0.530 mm × 1.0 µm) column. A certain amount of diethylene glycol monomethyl ether (DEGME) was added to the liquid sample as an internal standard substance. The conversion of glycerol and the yield of GC were calculated by the following formulas: (1) Glycerol conversion ( % ) = C GL , in − C GL , out C GL , in (2) GC selectivity ( % ) = C GC , out C GL , in − C GL , out (3) GC yield ( % ) = Glycerol conversion * GC selectivity where CGL,in, CGL,out, and CGC,out are the glycerol concentration before the reaction, glycerol concentration after the reaction, and GC concentration after the reaction, respectively. To study the reusability of the LaBO3 catalyst, the spent catalyst was filtrated, washed with ethanol, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C overnight. The catalytic test of the regenerated catalyst was recycled 3 times. The regenerated catalyst was also calcined at 700 °C for 3 h to decompose any surface contaminants and used for the recycling test for comparison. The activation energy (Ea) for this reaction was calculated by following formulas: (4) − r A = ( d C A d t ) = k C c o 2 m C A n (5) ( d C A d t ) = k C A n (6) 1 C A 2 − 1 C A o 2 = k ( t − t 0 ) (7) L n k = L n k 0 − E a R T where rA, C C O 2 , k0 and k are the instantaneous reaction rate, CO2 concentration after t hours reaction, pre-exponential factor and observed rate constant, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the LaBO3 perovskite catalysts Fig. 1 a shows the wide-angle XRD patterns of the three LaBO3 perovskite catalysts. The diffraction peaks of perovskite catalysts with different transition metals corresponded to the standard XRD patterns of LaFeO3 (JCPDS 34–1493), LaCoO3 (JCPDS 48–0123), and LaNiO3 (JCPDS 34–1077), respectively. The diffraction peaks attributed to La2O3, Fe3O4, Co3O4, and NiO were not observed in the patterns of LaFeO3, LaCoO3, and LaNiO3 catalysts. The above results indicated that the pure-phase LaBO3 perovskite catalysts with high crystallinity were successfully synthesized. The N2 adsorption−desorption isotherms of LaFeO3, LaCoO3, and LaNiO3 catalysts were displayed in Fig. 1b. The three catalysts showed typical type-IV curves with H3 hysteresis loops, suggesting that all catalysts possessed mesoporous structure due to the aggregation of nanoparticles. The BJH pore size distribution patterns indicated that the three LaBO3 catalysts had similar pore sizes of ∼30 nm (Fig. S1a-c). The textural properties of LaBO3 catalysts were also calculated and listed in Table S1. The LaBO3 catalysts with different transition metals exhibited comparable BET surface areas, pore volume, and average pore diameter. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images and elemental mapping images of LaFeO3 (Fig. 2a,d), LaCoO3 (Fig. 2b,e), and LaNiO3 (Fig. 2c,f). From Fig. 2a, the LaFeO3 catalyst consisted of nanoparticles with a size of 50–100 nm. In contrast, the LaCoO3 and LaNiO3 catalysts showed short rod-like morphology with a diameter of ∼100 nm (Fig. 2b,c). All three catalysts showed mesoporous structures formed by the aggregation of small particles, in accordance with the N2 physisorption results. The elemental distribution and composition of different catalysts were analyzed by the EDS mapping (Fig. 2d-f). The La, transition metal (Fe, Co, and Ni), and O were uniformly distributed in the nanoparticles for each sample. The detailed elemental composition of the LaBO3 perovskite catalysts is listed in Table S2. The La/transition metal molar ratio of LaFeO3, LaCoO3, and LaNiO3 was all close to 1, which was in good agreement with their perovskite structure. HRTEM was employed to further investigate the morphology and structure of LaBO3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 , the nanoparticles were aggregated and abundant mesopores were formed for each sample. Fig. 3d-f displayed a remarkable lattice spacing of 0.27 nm for the LaBO3 catalyst, corresponding to the (121) plane [43]. The (012) planes with lattice spacing distances of 0.38 nm were also observed for the LaCoO3 and LaNiO3 perovskites [44,45]. The planes marked in the HRTEM images were in line with the XRD result of patterns, suggesting the prepared catalysts had a crystalline perovskite structure. The surface composition and element chemical states of LaBO3 catalysts were characterized by the XPS test. Fig. 4 shows the Fe 2p, Co 2p, Ni 2p, and O1s spectra of LaFeO3, LaCoO3 and LaNiO3. The Fe 2p spectra (Fig. 4a) exhibited two prominent peaks at 710.2 eV and 724.6 eV, corresponding to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2. The fitted peaks located at 709.9 and 723.2 eV were the characteristics of Fe2+, while peaks at 711.1 and 724.2 eV were attributed to the Fe3+. In addition, another two peaks at 712.7 eV, and 725.5 eV can be assigned to the Fe4+ [46]. In the Co 2p spectra of LaCoO3 (Fig. 4b), the peaks at about 780.1 and 795.6 eV were corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 [45]. The deconvoluted peaks at 779.9 and 794.9 can be assigned to Co3+, while peaks located at 781.4 and 796.1 eV were attributed to Co2+ [47]. For the LaNiO3 catalyst, the XPS peak of Ni 2p was divided into four peaks, of which the peaks with binding energies of 853.6 and 855.3 eV were related to Ni2+ and Ni3+, respectively [48]. The other two fitted peaks at 851.6 and 849.7 eV corresponded to La 3d, which overlapped with the Ni 2p3/2 peaks. The element valence and distribution of LaBO3 calculated by Fe 2p, Co 2p and Ni 2p XPS analysis were listed in Table S3. The above results indicated that the transition metals in the LaBO3 catalyst possessed multiple valences, which could bring about unique surface properties like oxygen defects. The O 1 s XPS spectra of LaBO3 perovskite catalysts exhibited three prominent peaks at ∼529, ∼531, and ∼533 eV (Fig. 4d-f). The peak at ∼529 eV was assigned to the lattice oxygen (OI), while peaks located at ∼531 and ∼533 eV were due to chemisorbed oxygen (OII) and physisorbed oxygen (OIII), respectively [49]. It is well known that the high concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen (OII and OIII) was highly related to surface oxygen defects, resulting in the improved catalytic activity of the perovskite catalysts. In Fig. S2, the O 1 s spectra of the pure phase catalyst were split into two peaks: lattice oxygen at ∼531 eV and chemisorbed oxygen at ∼532 eV [50,51]. Hence, the (OII + OIII)/(OI + OII + OIII) ratio of LaBO3 catalysts was also calculated and listed in Table 1 . The surface oxygen concentration of LaBO3 was in the following order: LaNiO3 >LaFeO3 >LaCoO3 >La2O3. Among all catalysts, the LaNiO3 had the highest (OII + OIII)/(OI + OII + OIII) ratio, corresponding to the highest concentration of oxygen defects. The EPR was further used to detect the surface oxygen defects of LaBO3 and La2O3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 a, all the EPR signals of LaBO3 were bimodal with g ≈ 2.003 as the center of symmetry except for La2O3, indicating that unpaired electrons were captured by oxygen defects. According to Fig. S2 and Table 1, La2O3 had the lowest concentration of oxygen defects which was proved by the feeble signal in Fig. 5a. Obviously, LaFeO3, LaCoO3, and LaNiO3 perovskites all had oxygen defects, which were in good agreement with the XPS results as discussed above. Apart from oxygen defects, basicity is another key factor that affects the catalytic activity of perovskites. To compare the difference in the basic sites, CO2-TPD tests were conducted with the results shown in Fig. 5b. The desorption curves for each catalyst could be divided into three regions, corresponding to weak (50–200 °C), medium (200–500 °C), strong (500–700 °C) basic sites from low to high temperatures. According to the literature, the basic strength had a significant influence on the catalytic activity [23]. The detailed basic strength analysis results are listed in Table 1. The medium and strong basic sites took up >80 % of the total basic amounts for all samples. It was suggested that La2O3 had the highest strong basic site proportion, while LaCoO3 had the highest medium basic site proportion. The total weak and medium basic sites of different catalysts were in the order as follows: LaCoO3 >LaNiO3 >LaFeO3 >La2O3. 3.2 Catalytic performance for glycerol carbonylation into GC The catalytic activity tests were carried out using 0.2 g of catalyst, 0.92 g of glycerol as reactant, 3.12 g of 2-cyanopyridine as dehydrating agent, and 10 mL of DMF as solvent. The carbonylation reaction proceeded under 3 MPa of CO2 at 150 °C for 12 h. The conversion, selectivity, and GC yield are listed in Fig. 6 . The highest GC yield was achieved by the LaCoO3 catalyst with a glycerol conversion of 30.5 % and GC selectivity of 60.5 %. The conversion of glycerol for the different catalysts was in the following order: LaNiO3 >LaFeO3 >LaCoO3 >La2O3, which complied with the order of the oxygen defects concentration on the catalyst surface. From Fig. 6, the activity of all the perovskite catalysts was higher than La2O3, suggesting that the perovskite structure was beneficial to the catalytic reaction. Kulal et al. reported that Zn-Doped CeO2 nanorods with enhancing oxygen vacancies demonstrated improved capacity for CO2 activation [29]. Such observation was also confirmed by the research work of Liu et al., in which catalysts with more oxygen defects also greatly increased the conversion [24]. However, oxygen defects usually exhibited a weak effect on product selectivity. In our work, the selectivity of GC was in the following order: LaCoO3 >LaNiO3 >LaFeO3 >La2O3, which was in line with the order of total weak and medium basic site amounts. When weak and medium basic sites proportion increased, the GC selectivity increased accordingly. More weak and medium basic sites of catalysts may contribute to more adsorbed and activated intermediate which was then favorable for the reaction because the decomposition of the intermediate can form more GC product. Li et al. also suggested that the strong basicity of catalysts was adverse to the activation of CO2 [28]. Hence, we think that the strong basic sites could facilitate the side reaction to form products with high molecular weights, and thus reduce the selectivity of GC. As a result, the LaCoO3 catalyst with the highest amounts of weak and medium basic sites achieved the best GC yield. The catalytic performance of the LaCoO3 catalyst was also comparable with most of the reported glycerol carbonylation catalysts in the literature (Table S4). The optimal reaction conditions for the carbonylation of glycerol with CO2 into GC were then studied using the LaCoO3 catalyst. Fig. 7 a shows the performance of glycerol carbonylation at different temperatures. With ramping temperature from 130 to 190 °C, glycerol conversion increased from 15.2 % to 52.1 %, indicating high temperature favored the activation of reactants. However, the GC selectivity initially increased from 0.9 % to 60.5 %, but then decreased to 16.4 %. The highest GC selectivity was obtained at a reaction temperature of 150 °C. Too high a temperature could result in some side reactions that deceased the GC selectivity. CO2 pressure was a key parameter that determined the reaction performance because CO2 was hard to activate and inserted into glycerol molecular. Catalytic reactions under different CO2 pressures (1–5 Mpa) were carried out to study their effect on the activity. As shown in Fig. 7b, when pressure increased from 1 to 5 MPa, glycerol conversion increased gradually. The GC selectivity exhibited a volcano-like curve, which increased sharply to 72.4 % from 1 to 2 MPa, and then gradually decreased to 42.1 % at 5 MPa. It could be seen that improving the CO2 pressure promoted the activation of CO2, owing to the improved CO2 absorption in DMF at high pressure and enhanced CO2 activation. However, too high pressure also promoted side reactions and decreased the selectivity of the target product, which was possibly due to more carbonates formed on the surface of the catalyst, which increased the amount of strong basic sites. The glycerol conversion and GC selectivity at different reaction times are shown in Fig. 7c. The glycerol conversion did not exhibit a significant change from the 6–18 h reaction. However, GC selectivity increased from 40.0 to 72.4 % and then decreased to 52.6 % with the increasing reaction times. During the initial 6 h, the intermediate products could form, which were consumed and converted into GC to improve its selectivity. However, excess consumption of dehydrating agents contributed to side reactions after 12 h reaction, having adverse effects on the GC selectivity. Fig. 7d shows the results of glycerol carbonylation and GC selectivity using different amounts of 2-cyanopyridine as a dehydrating agent. When the 2-cyanopyridine concentration increased from 0 to 30 mmol, both conversion and selectivity displayed an upward trend. The ever-increasing catalytic conversion suggested that the dehydrating agent could effectively break the thermodynamic equilibrium by removing the by-product water. However, GC selectivity decreased when further increasing the 2-cyanopyridine concentration to 40 mmol. However, too high a dehydrating agent amount in the reaction mixture could accelerate the side reactions. For example, Su et al. found that 2-cyanopyridine can react with CO2 to form a five-membered ring intermediate [52], which will react with glycerol to form a new intermediate, and GC would be achieved after several steps. So, the concentration of 2-cyanopyridine had a strong effect on the catalytic performance. The effect of catalyst amount on the catalytic performance was also studied with the results shown in Fig. S3. The glycerol conversion increased from 21.7 to 26.3 % and GC selectivity increased from 54.2 to 72.4 % when the catalyst amount increased from 0.7 to 1.4 %wt. Further increment of catalyst amount had no obvious effect on the catalyst performance. 3.3 Catalyst reusability performance Catalyst reusability experiments of LaCoO3 were conducted under the optimized reaction conditions with the results shown in Fig. 8 . The glycerol conversion of used catalysts without calcination increased slightly after each regeneration (Fig. 8a). The FTIR spectrum in Fig. S4 indicated that many carbonates were formed on the surface of the catalyst after catalytic reaction, which can not be removed by simple cleaning and drying. Such carbonates were also observed on the surface of the used Ce0.98Zr0.02O2 catalyst by FTIR in literature [26]. The formed carbonates contributed to the high amount of strong basic sites which improved the glycerol conversion (Fig. S5). However, GC selectivity greatly decreased from 72.4 to 31.1 % after 4 times usage. For comparison, the used LaCoO3 catalyst was also calcined at 700 °C in the air atmosphere. Surprisingly, the catalytic performance remains almost unchanged in the 4 cycles test (Fig. 8b). Calcination treatment at high temperatures can effectively remove these carbonates from the surface of the used LaCoO3 catalyst. In a word, the LaCoO3 perovskite catalyst demonstrated excellent reusability performance in the glycerol carbonylation reaction. 3.4 Reaction kinetics The reaction kinetics of glycerol carbonylation with LaCoO3 was studied. The linear fitting curves for the reaction time dependence of CA, ln(CA/CAo), 1/CA 2, and 1/CA are shown in Fig. 9 and S6. The CA, CAo, and R2 referred to the concentration of glycerol at time t, initial concentration of glycerol and coefficient of determination. The higher R2 values represented a better degree of agreement between the fitting curve and experimental data. As shown in Fig. S6, three fitting curves corresponded to zeroth-, first-, and second-order reactions, respectively. The R2 values of all three fittings were lower than 0.8, suggesting that the glycerol carbonylation over the LaCoO3 catalyst did not follow the proposed reaction orders. Fig. 9 shows that the experimental data followed the third-order reaction very well. In the literature, a pseudo-third-order reaction was also observed at the ZIF-67 surface for the catalytic glycerol carbonylation reaction due to the formation of CO2 and glycerol colloid at the catalyst surface [25]. The activation energy of glycerol carbonylation on the LaCoO3 catalyst was calculated as 43.0 kJ/mol according to Eqs. 4–7. 4 Conclusion In this work, LaFeO3, LaCoO3, and LaNiO3 perovskite catalysts were successfully synthesized by the sol-gel method. The obtained catalysts all possessed mesoporous structures formed by aggregation of nanoparticles. The catalysts were employed for the carbonylation of glycerol into GC, among which LaCoO3 exhibited the highest GC yield as compared to LaFeO3, LaNiO3, and La2O3. The XPS and CO2-TPD tests suggested that surface oxygen defect was correlated with the glycerol conversion, while the concentration of weak and medium basic sites was related to GC selectivity. On the one hand, perovskite catalysts formed by La and transition metals had more surface oxygen defects than La2O3, so they delivered higher catalytic activity. On the other hand, the higher weak and medium basic sites contributed to higher GC selectivity by retarding the side reactions. The optimal reaction conditions for the glycerol carbonylation over LaCoO3 catalyst were determined as 150 °C for 12 h at 3 MPa in the presence of 30 mmol 2-cyanopyridine as a dehydrating agent, achieving glycerol conversion of 26.3 % with GC selectivity of 72.4 %. The LaCoO3 catalyst also maintained high activity during 4 recycling tests, suggesting its excellent reusability and stability. coredata.dc:description: LaBO3 (B = Fe, Co, Ni) perovskite catalysts were prepared by the sol-gel method. The physical properties and active sites were characterized by XRD, BET, SEM, TEM, XPS, EPR, and CO2-TPD. The results indicated that catalysts had fine perovskite structure and high crystallinity. The as-synthesized catalysts were used for the glycerol carbonylation with CO2 to glycerol carbonate (GC). The LaCoO3 exhibited high conversion and selectivity of 26.3 and 72.4 % at a reaction temperature of 150 °C for 12 h under CO2 pressure of 3 MPa in the presence of 2-cyanopyridine with DMF as the solvent. It was found that surface oxygen defects favored the glycerol conversion, while the high concentration of total weak and medium basic sites promoted the GC selectivity. The LaCoO3 also displayed excellent reusability performance, indicating its great potential in industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Lanthanum-based perovskite catalysts for the glycerol carbonylation to glycerol carbonate: Effects of oxygen defects and basicity
